Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Community Rebuilding after Disaster

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
How do damaged or destroyed communities rebuild themselves after disasters, such as war and extreme weather events? Does the extent of destruction matter? Does a totally destroyed community rebuild in the same way and as successfully as a less extensively damaged one? The research supported by this award addresses these questions through an ethnographic study of post-disaster community rebuilding. The researcher takes up the questions by looking at the what it means to reconstitute a place, not just as a physical location but as site where people can once again feel at home. In the wake of multiple disasters that have torn people from their homes and damaged communities throughout the United States, people are asking if they can return, if they should return, if indeed there is a community to return to. It is critical that policy makers and social scientists better understand what it will take to put people's lives back together, not just as households but also as communities.

The research will be carried out by University of Kentucky anthropology doctoral student, Pathmanesan Sanmugeswaran, who is supervised by Dr. Mark Whitaker. The research takes a comparative design approach. The researcher has identified two post-disaster communities in Sri Lanka. One community was totally destroyed and the inhabitants are returning to rebuild after 26 years, and the other was physically damaged and social disrupted but nonetheless remained intact. This contrast in an otherwise similar socio-cultural and geographic environmental context provides a scientifically useful and rare experimental opportunity that would not be available in the United States, although the results will be generalizable to many other contexts. Data will be gathered through semi-structured interviews, participant observation, and cultural mapping. Sampling will be structured to represent the full range of socio-cultural variation, including caste, gender, and age. Particular attention will be paid to how traditional notions of community, which centered around combined ideas of community and religion, are remade in the two contrasting post-disaster situations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation research grant on community rebuilding funded a year of cultural anthropological fieldwork in 2019 in two villages, Inuvil and Nagaleswaran, in the Jaffna District, a northern peninsular part of the south Asian nation of Sri Lanka. This peninsula is occupied mostly by members of the Tamil ethnic group, the majority of whom are Hindu. The Sri Lankan state, however, is largely controlled by the demographically predominate Sinhalese ethnic group, most of whom are Buddhist. These differences in ethnicity, numbers, and religion, for complex historical reasons too involved to discuss here, helped lead to a twenty-six year long civil war (1983-2009) during which the Jaffa District was much fought over. Within Jaffna, Inuvil village was deeply affected socially and culturally; and Nagaleswaran village was utterly destroyed -- its physical structures razed to the ground, and its human population scattered and only allowed to return after 2015.

Since the people of both villages were very much still in the process of rebuilding their villages in 2019, this project focused on how they were using their own local, cultural practices to help them do so. In this case, this meant testing the hypothesis that the Tamil people rebuilding these two villages were being guided by a specific, learned, cultural practice of remembering, experiencing, and arguing about their villages called, for research purposes, “village or village-temple consciousness”, with “temple” here referring to the way many Jaffna Tamils used Hindu temples as central focal points of local sociological, geographical, and political organization. For example, in Naguleswaran the first structures rebuilt by people returning to that village, preceding even reconstruction of their own old homes, were temples.

This hypothesis was confirmed by a year of research involving direct observation of rebuilding efforts and extensive interviews with 114 people involved in them. That is, the research confirmed, first, that such a cultural practice existed; second, that “village-temple” consciousness concerns were, indeed, guiding most local rebuilding activities. But the research supported additional conclusions as well. First, that “village-temple consciousness” as a shared practice was itself also constantly being negotiated as various outside forces – changes in national politics, global economics, caste and gender norms, and local demography – challenged widely shared assumptions and social and physical certainties. Second, that since “village-temple consciousness” as a prewar practice had favored the Jaffna district’s dominant caste group, other caste groups were challenging this postwar by offering alternative formulations of village consciousness. Overall, though, the key finding of this project is that rebuilding efforts in Jaffa cannot be understood apart from the “village-temple consciousness” Jaffna people themselves are using to bring to such efforts about.

 Of course, the question this research has answered is part of a broader question cultural anthropologists ask when doing research on societies that have experienced a disaster of one sort or another. That question is, how do people in communities that have been destroyed by war or natural disaster use their own local cultural resources – including those related to how they have learned to experience, plan for, and talk about their own communities -- to help rebuild them? This is both a practical and a scientific cultural anthropological concern. It is practical, of course, because communities that have been damaged or destroyed must be rebuilt if they are to survive, and in general such rebuilding must be done by the people who live there. To disregard the way they themselves culturally envision and experience their communities when rebuilding them would be to increase the risk of such restorative projects failing due to misunderstanding where, and in what order, support should be offered or supplied. This being the case, it is worth knowing how rebuilding has taken place in specific cases, such as in Jaffna’s villages, to figure out how rebuilding might be better supported elsewhere.

But for cultural anthropology this project involved answering an important, general, scientific question. Does how communities rebuild themselves reveal something important about what they are? Yes. Because cultural anthropologists assume (as an axiom of the field) that learned cultural practices always play a substantial role in human activity, it is important to describe exactly how particular cultural practices do so in specific instances. Since rebuilding in the wake of a disaster is a challenge that, alas, may confront any human community, it is important to ask how people in such communities use their own cultural practices related to designing and maintaining communities to help them do so. Hence, by confirming, ethnographically, that the cultural practice of  “village-temple consciousness” helped guide rebuilding in Jaffna, Tamil, Sri Lanka, this project also confirms, or at least strongly suggests, that anthropologists working anywhere in post-disaster locations must look for whatever local cultural practices people might be using there to make communities disasters have turned into mere places back into communally recognized homes
